title: 109_s1260
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005" requires consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2719) is amended to specify conditions for Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations as of October 17, 1988, to engage in gaming activities on certain lands within the state. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to exempt Indian lands in Oklahoma without reservations from certain gaming restrictions, subject to consultation with relevant authorities within 60 miles of the land. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act allows for gaming establishments on Indian lands within 60 miles, if it benefits the tribe and does not negatively impact nearby entities. The Secretary's decision requires the approval of the state Governor and legislative body. The Secretary's determination for gaming activities on Indian lands requires approval from the state Governor and legislative body. This does not apply to existing gaming facilities. The land must be within the tribe's primary location as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary determines the primary location of the tribe for gaming activities on Indian lands, based on the geographic, social, and historical nexus to the land. This includes land owned by or held in trust for the tribe within designated geographical areas. The Secretary designates the geographical area for financial assistance and social service programs for the Indian tribe, including land on or near a reservation, or the area where over 50% of the tribe's members reside. The Indian tribe must be composed mainly of tribal members and located within their historical residence area or last recognized reservation in a different state. The Indian tribe must conduct gaming activities on one contiguous parcel of Indian lands, regardless of other provisions in the Act. SEC. 3. TRIBAL GAMING ORDINANCES. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2710) is amended to include provisions regarding the conduct of class II gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow Indian tribes to conduct class II gaming activities on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for their benefit. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow Indian tribes to conduct class II gaming activities on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for their benefit, with specific guidelines for conducting such activities on Indian lands. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow Indian tribes to conduct class II gaming activities on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for their benefit, with specific guidelines for conducting class III gaming activities on newly acquired trust lands. The definition of "State" is clarified to include the Governor and legislative body of the State. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow Indian tribes to conduct class II gaming activities on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for their benefit, with specific guidelines for conducting class III gaming activities on newly acquired trust lands. The definition of "State" is clarified to include the Governor and legislative body of the State. SEC. 4. INVESTIGATION AND APPROVAL. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to grant powers to the Chairman and the Commission regarding the approval or disapproval of individuals or entities with financial interests in gaming activities. The Commission is required to identify the top 10 persons or entities involved in gaming activities. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to grant powers to the Chairman and the Commission to identify the top 10 persons or entities with financial interests in gaming activities and conduct background investigations on them. Additionally, tribal gaming ordinances must ensure proper oversight of these individuals and entities. The Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require background investigations on tribal gaming commissioners, key employees, management officials, and gaming enterprise key employees. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to increase Commission funding from $8,000,000 to $16,000,000. Ongoing oversight of key individuals in tribal gaming enterprises is also required. SEC. 5. CHANGING USE OF INDIAN LAND. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require Indian tribes to submit an environmental impact statement and obtain Secretary's consent before using Indian lands for gaming. The Act and its amendments will not impact any existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulated under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
